thread.title: A-B may pull support from St. Pat's parade in Boston
thread.title_full: A-B may pull support from St. Pat's parade in Boston

author: Joe Holleman St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: A-B may pull support from St. Pat's parade in Boston
text:
Get your daily dose of local news right here. Close Buy Now Jon Gitchoff 
Jason Gallahue of St. Louis (right) throws beads to the crowd during the 47th Annual St. Patrick's Day Parade on Market Street in downtown St. Louis on Saturday, March 12, 2016. Photo by Jon Gitchoff The Associated Press 
FILE - In this March 20, 2016 file photo, members of OutVets, a group of gay military veterans, march in the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade in Boston's South Boston neighborhood. The group said Wednesday, March 8, 2017, it was denied permission to march in the 2017 Boston St. Patrick's Day parade just two years after organizers made the ground-breaking decision to allow gay groups to participate for the first time. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File) A-B may pull support from St. Pat's parade in Boston Buy Now Jon Gitchoff 
Jason Gallahue of St. Louis (right) throws beads to the crowd during the 47th Annual St. Patrick's Day Parade on Market Street in downtown St. Louis on Saturday, March 12, 2016. Photo by Jon Gitchoff The Associated Press 
FILE - In this March 20, 2016 file photo, members of OutVets, a group of gay military veterans, march in the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade in Boston's South Boston neighborhood. The group said Wednesday, March 8, 2017, it was denied permission to march in the 2017 Boston St. Patrick's Day parade just two years after organizers made the ground-breaking decision to allow gay groups to participate for the first time. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File) 
Our town's mega-brewer Anheuser-Busch is poised to pull its green from Boston’s St. Patrick’s Day Parade on March 19. 
A-B announced its intentions after parade organizers decided to bar OutVets, a group of gay veterans , from marching in the parade March 19. 
After the group was told it could not participate in the parade, A-B issued the following statement: 
"We are disappointed to learn OutVets, who have proudly served this country, have been denied entry. We are re-evaluating our participation in this event," the company said. 
A group spokesman told Boston media that the group was barred because its logo includes a rainbow, and the parade prohibits displays related to sexual orientation. 
The parade is organized by the Allied War Veterans Council, which allowed the group to march in the last two year's parades. 
After an emergency meeting Friday afternoon, OutVets' executive director, Bryan Bishop, told The Associated Press that his group was told they could participate, but only if they removed the rainbow from their banners and jackets. 
Bishop said OutVets refused, noting that the rainbow is a symbol of gay pride and solidarity. 
Meanwhile in St. Louis, the city's 48th annual St. Patrick’s Day Parade begins Saturday at noon, with Anheuser-Busch as a main sponsor. 
The dignitaries stepping out first will include Mayor Francis G. Slay ; St. Louis Irish Consul Joseph McGlynn , Jr.; Mary Mitchell O’Connor , Ireland’s jobs ministers; and the honorary marshal, John Saunders , president and chief executive officer of FleishmanHillard. Police Chief Sam Dotson and Fire Chief Dennis Jenkerson will head the first responders' entry. 
The parade steps off from 20th and Market Streets and proceeds east on Market to Broadway and then south on Broadway where it will disband at Clark Street. Organizers expect about 130 units and 5,000 marchers. 
The food and beverage event's Shamrock Village's food and beverage booths will operate from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tags
